Saturday afternoon in the neighborhood of Pikesville had an undecisive engagement with the cadets of City College and Polytechnic.
The Hopkins force was convoying an imaginary wagon train
from Pikesville to Mt. Washington, and while passing down a
woodland road was fired upon by
several of the unseen enemy. Undaunted by this the battalion
pressed on, expecting -every moment to receive news of the enemy's location from patrols, which
had been sent out to reconnoiter;
but as no news of any consequence
arrived, it seemed that the patrols
had been either captured or lost

The convoy, under the command
of Major Linton, after wading
through miles of mud up to their
shoetops, finally neared the enemy. The convoy prepared to attack, and advanced bravely on the
foe, part of which was entrenched
in a dense thicket at the bottom
of a gentle slope. The main body
of the enemy, however, was keeping up an imaginary rapid fire
from a hill to the left. After
advancing by rushes, Captain
Thompson led his company in a
victorious rush upon the enemy's
detachment in the thicket, and
succeeded in overwhelming it.

The New Absence Rules.

There is little doubt that,in protesting against the severity of the
new rules regarding absences, the
Student Council truly representsthe opinion of the undergraduate
student body. THE NEWS-LETTER
believes that such a protest, uttered, not in the spirit of revolt,
but in the spirit of appeal, merits
the earnest consideration of. the
Hopkins faculty.
It is generally understood by
the great majority of Hopkins stu(Milts that the new rules owe their
promulgation solely to the great
increase which has come about in
the University enrollment. Technically, even in the past, each student was supposed to attend every
class in every ()Ile of his courses,
or to submit to his instructor a
legitimate excuse. The unpleasad fact must be faced that the
leniency with which this requirement was interpreted, in the case
of a small minority of Hopkins

men, led to an amount of "cutting" which was a gross abuse of
the laxity with which the rule
was enforced. Undeniably, men
who "cut" as a matter of habit
should be made to pay the penalty—in this premise, the great
majority of students heartily
concur.
At the same time, it is undeniably true that; in the past, many
men have cut one or two of their
classes in a course without any
detriment whatsoever to the character of the work which they were
doing or to the grade which they
received. So much has this been
the case that it had come to be regarded as an unwritten privilege
—never, indeed, acknowledged by
the faculty, but never. den
- ied by
them—that a man who was keeping well up in his work could absent himself from a class or two
each term without giving an explanation of his absence, and
without having his grade lowered.
Nor was this unwritten privilege
regarded by the students so much
as an excuse for "cutting" as
merely a manifestation of the
greater freedom of action which
attendance at a University is generally supposed to bring.
It is the abridgement of this
freedom which the students resent more than the actual rule itself. Yet, there also enters into
the ciuestion the fact that a man
may not go to a class for a reason which, entirely legitimate in
itself, is too personal to be submitted to a faculty board. In
such cases—and the cases undoubtedly do exist—it does not
seem quite necessary that, even
though he has made up the work
which he has missed, the man's
mark for the term should still be
lowered.
THE NEWS-LETTER, therefore, respectfully submits for the consideration of the faculty the following amendment to the rules:
Let Rule 3 be made to read:
"After the second unexcused absence, the absences will count
against the student's mark in the
subject concerned. If his work in
the subject is below 8, every such
absence will be counted."
Such an amendment would not
affect fhe efficacy of the rules in
guarding against the evil which
they strive to prevent, and, at the
same time, would remove every
shadow of justification for' the student body's failure to appreciate
the necessity of their enforcement.

voice, could utter the thought
now uppermost, there would be a
deep, quick, hearty acknowledgment of the bounty of Johns Hopkins.

so wise promoting at once the
physical,
' intellectual and moral
welfare of his fellow men,
awakens universal surprise and
admiration, and calls for our perpetual thanks.
In respect to the giver, I can
say but little to you, the citizens
of Baltimore, who knew him so
well; who remember his industry,
sagacity and intellectual force;
who have tested his integrity, and
found that his word was as good
as his bond; who recall his foresight, his enterprise, and his belief in the future of this city and
State; who recollect that more
than once in financial crises he
hazarded his own fortune for the
protection of others; who heard,
it may be from his own lips, the
motives and hopes which prompted these royal gifts; who believed
that great acquisitions involve
great responsibilities, but who
know how hard it was for one
long accustomed to power to
yield that power to others; to
you, his fellow-citizens who saw
benefactor
the steps by which this'
toiled upward to the temple of
Fortune, and there unsatisfied,
went higher, by more arduous
steps, to the temple of Charity,
where he bestowed his gifts.

As we, my friends, are called
upon to develop a university, it
becomes important not only to distinguish its essential idea from
'that of any other institution, but
also to form a clear 'conception
of its special province; of various
plans which have governed its organization; of the good which it
promotes; of the questions which
are settled; of the questions
which are not settled, and especially of the bearing of all these
points on our land, our times, our
foundation. Thus only shall we
make a contribution to the intellectual agencies of this country,
and add a positive gain to American learning and education in the
second century of the Republic.
The tenor of my remarks has
implied perhaps more diversity of
opinion than really exists in respect to universities. The truth
is, most institutions are not.free
to build anew; they can only readjust. It has been playfully said
that "traditions and conditions"
impede their progress. But whatever may be the concrete difficulties on many abstract principles
there is little need of controversy.
Our effort will be to accept that
which is determined — to avoid
that which is obsolescent, to study
that which is doubtful—"slowly
making haste."

There is no better way, The News-Letter deems, of commemorating the forty-first anniversary of the founding of the
University—an anniversary to which the removal to Homewood
gives epoch-making significance—than by publishing the inaugural
address of the University's first president.
The part which Daniel Coit Gilman played in the conception
and development of the Johns Hopkins University is told, in better
words than we can command, by his biographer, Fabian Franklin:
"His was the co-ordinating mind and the decisive voice in the
shaping of the University's character and the determination of its
policies. The policy of taking time to permit the beginnings to
develop,.of letting the University grow into its true self rather
than forcing it into a rigid mold, appealed to him particularly; and
it is to the combination of the caution involved in this policy and
the boldness of his fundamental purpose that the signal success
achieved by the University from the beginning must be ascribed."
What is reproduced on this page is only a part of that
first inaugural address; but it is sufficient to show clearly the
ideals which the Johns Hopkins was created to fulfill—the ideals
which must continue to guide the University in the future, as they
have guided it in the past.
Is, then, anything settled in respect to university education?
Much, very much. Can we draw
a statement of what is agreed
upon? At any rate we can try.
The schedule will include twelve
points on which there seems to be
a general agreement.
1. All sciences are worthy of
promotion; or in other words, it
is useless to dispute whether literature or science should receive
most attention, or whether there
is any essential difference between
the old and the new education.
2. Religion has nothing to fear
from science, and science need not
be afraid of religion. Religion
claims to interpret the word of
God, and science reveals the laws
of God. The ' interpreters may

blunder, but truths are immutable, eternal and never in conflict.
3. Remote utility is quite as
worthy to be thought of as immediate advantage. Those ventures are not always most sagacious that expect a return on the
morrow. It sometimes pays to
send our argosies across the seas;
to make investments with an eye
to slow but sure returns. So is it
always in the promotion of science.
4. As it is impossible for any
university to encourage with
equal freedom all branches of
learning, a selection must be made
by enlightened governors, and
that selection must depend on the
requirements and deficiencies of a
given people, in a given period.

There is no absolute standard of
preference. What is more important at one time or in one place
may be less needed elsewhere and
otherwise.
5. Individual students cannot
pursue all branches of learning,
and must be allowed to select,
under the guidance of those who
are appointed to counsel them.
Nor can able professors be governed by routine. Teachers and
pupils must be allowed great freedom in their method of work.
Recitations, lectures, examinations, laboratories, libraries, field
exercises, travels, •are all legitimate means of culture.
6. The best scholars will almost
invariably be those who make special attainments on the foundation of a broad and liberal culture.
7. The best teachers are usually
those who are free, competent,
and willing to make original researches in the library and the
laboratory.
8. The best investigators are
usually those who have also the
responsibilities of instruction,
gaining thus the incitement of
colleagues, the encouragement of
pupils, the observation of the public.
9. Universities should bestow
their honors with a sparing hand;
their benefits most freely.
10. A university cannot be created in a day; it is a slow growth.
The University of Berlin has been
quoted as a proof of the contrary.
That was indeed a quick success,
but in an old, compact country,
crowded with learned men eager
to assemble at the Prussian court.
It was a change of base rather
than a sudden development.
11. The object of the university
is to develop character—to make
men. It misses its aim if it produces learned pedants, or simple
artisans, or cunning sophists, or
pretentious practitioners. Its purport is not so much to impart
knowledge to the pupils as to
whet the appetite, exhibit methods, develop powers, strengthen
judgment, and invigorate the intellectual and moral forces. It
should prepare for the service of
society a class of students who
will be wise, thoughtful, progressive guides in whatever department of 'work or thought they
may be engaged.
12. Universities easily fall into
ruts. Almost every epoch requires
a fresh start.
If these twelve points are conceded, our task is simplified,
though it is still difficult. It is
to apply these principles to Baltimore in 1876.

THE INAUGURAL ADDRESS OF PRESIDENT DANIEL COIT GILMAN, 1876
If this assembly, with one
voice, could utter the thought
now uppermost, there would be a
deep, quick, hearty acknowledgment of the bounty of Johns Hopkins.
His beneficence, so free, so great,
so wise promoting at once the
physical,
' intellectual and moral
welfare of his fellow men,
awakens universal surprise and
admiration, and calls for our perpetual thanks.
In respect to the giver, I can
say but little to you, the citizens
of Baltimore, who knew him so
well; who remember his industry,
sagacity and intellectual force;
who have tested his integrity, and
found that his word was as good
as his bond; who recall his foresight, his enterprise, and his belief in the future of this city and
State; who recollect that more
than once in financial crises he
hazarded his own fortune for the
protection of others; who heard,
it may be from his own lips, the
motives and hopes which prompted these royal gifts; who believed
that great acquisitions involve
great responsibilities, but who
know how hard it was for one
long accustomed to power to
yield that power to others; to
you, his fellow-citizens who saw
benefactor
the steps by which this'
toiled upward to the temple of
Fortune, and there unsatisfied,
went higher, by more arduous
steps, to the temple of Charity,
where he bestowed his gifts.
*
*
*'
*
*
As we, my friends, are called
upon to develop a university, it
becomes important not only to distinguish its essential idea from
'that of any other institution, but
also to form a clear 'conception
of its special province; of various
plans which have governed its organization; of the good which it
promotes; of the questions which
are settled; of the questions
which are not settled, and especially of the bearing of all these
points on our land, our times, our
foundation. Thus only shall we
make a contribution to the intellectual agencies of this country,
and add a positive gain to American learning and education in the
second century of the Republic.
The tenor of my remarks has
implied perhaps more diversity of
opinion than really exists in respect to universities. The truth
is, most institutions are not.free
to build anew; they can only readjust. It has been playfully said
that "traditions and conditions"
impede their progress. But whatever may be the concrete difficulties on many abstract principles
there is little need of controversy.
Our effort will be to accept that
which is determined — to avoid
that which is obsolescent, to study
that which is doubtful—"slowly
making haste."

There is no better way, The News-Letter deems, of commemorating the forty-first anniversary of the founding of the
University—an anniversary to which the removal to Homewood
gives epoch-making significance—than by publishing the inaugural
address of the University's first president.
The part which Daniel Coit Gilman played in the conception
and development of the Johns Hopkins University is told, in better
words than we can command, by his biographer, Fabian Franklin:
"His was the co-ordinating mind and the decisive voice in the
shaping of the University's character and the determination of its
policies. The policy of taking time to permit the beginnings to
develop,.of letting the University grow into its true self rather
than forcing it into a rigid mold, appealed to him particularly; and
it is to the combination of the caution involved in this policy and
the boldness of his fundamental purpose that the signal success
achieved by the University from the beginning must be ascribed."
What is reproduced on this page is only a part of that
first inaugural address; but it is sufficient to show clearly the
ideals which the Johns Hopkins was created to fulfill—the ideals
which must continue to guide the University in the future, as they
have guided it in the past.
Is, then, anything settled in respect to university education?
Much, very much. Can we draw
a statement of what is agreed
upon? At any rate we can try.
The schedule will include twelve
points on which there seems to be
a general agreement.
1. All sciences are worthy of
promotion; or in other words, it
is useless to dispute whether literature or science should receive
most attention, or whether there
is any essential difference between
the old and the new education.
2. Religion has nothing to fear
from science, and science need not
be afraid of religion. Religion
claims to interpret the word of
God, and science reveals the laws
of God. The ' interpreters may

blunder, but truths are immutable, eternal and never in conflict.
3. Remote utility is quite as
worthy to be thought of as immediate advantage. Those ventures are not always most sagacious that expect a return on the
morrow. It sometimes pays to
send our argosies across the seas;
to make investments with an eye
to slow but sure returns. So is it
always in the promotion of science.
4. As it is impossible for any
university to encourage with
equal freedom all branches of
learning, a selection must be made
by enlightened governors, and
that selection must depend on the
requirements and deficiencies of a
given people, in a given period.

DANIEL COIT GILMAN

There is no absolute standard of
preference. What is more important at one time or in one place
may be less needed elsewhere and
otherwise.
5. Individual students cannot
pursue all branches of learning,
and must be allowed to select,
under the guidance of those who
are appointed to counsel them.
Nor can able professors be governed by routine. Teachers and
pupils must be allowed great freedom in their method of work.
Recitations, lectures, examinations, laboratories, libraries, field
exercises, travels, •are all legitimate means of culture.
6. The best scholars will almost
invariably be those who make special attainments on the foundation of a broad and liberal culture.
7. The best teachers are usually
those who are free, competent,
and willing to make original researches in the library and the
laboratory.
8. The best investigators are
usually those who have also the
responsibilities of instruction,
gaining thus the incitement of
colleagues, the encouragement of
pupils, the observation of the public.
9. Universities should bestow
their honors with a sparing hand;
their benefits most freely.
10. A university cannot be created in a day; it is a slow growth.
The University of Berlin has been
quoted as a proof of the contrary.
That was indeed a quick success,
but in an old, compact country,
crowded with learned men eager
to assemble at the Prussian court.
It was a change of base rather
than a sudden development.
11. The object of the university
is to develop character—to make
men. It misses its aim if it produces learned pedants, or simple
artisans, or cunning sophists, or
pretentious practitioners. Its purport is not so much to impart
knowledge to the pupils as to
